author: nucleuspoc
body:
Hello, 
This isn't a bug, more asking for advice. I am currently trying to install modules onto my Powershell instance installed on my Linux machine. I installed it all ok, log into Powershellusing 'pwsh' and tried to add a module however it doesn't seem to want to be added. 
Module: ```Save-Module -Name HPOneView.400 -Path /opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0 ```
which states: “command was found in the module '<ModuleName>', but the module could not be loaded"

Can this be done via a Linux instance or can I only add modules in a Windows instance of Powershell?

Thank you in advance

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Just curious!  Have you tried to save the module to the /home/user folder?
I wonder it it works.

:)

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
I have done a test using Windows 10 Ubuntu and seems to work when using 'Import-Module' from the  User home folder.  

You may want to try using "sudo pwsh" and then do the "Save-Module" as you're saving to a protected area.

:)

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Ah! Check the PSModulePath variable:
```
$Env:PSModulePath
/home/maxt/.local/share/powershell/Modules:/usr/local/share/powershell/Modules:/opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0/Modules
```
You'll probably need to save it under "/opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0/Modules" and not "/opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0".

Or, add the module folder to the $Env:PSModulePath.  This may fix the issue.

:)

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
> which states: “command was found in the module '', but the module could not be loaded"

@nucleuspoc Did you see this when running `Save-Module` or when running a function from the module you saved? If it's the former, it seems indicating the module `PowerShellGet` cannot be auto-loaded. Can you run "Import-Module PowerShellGet" and see what error you get?

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
@nucleuspoc,

So I went overboard on this issue.  So, check the help documentation at: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/PowershellGet/Save-Module?view=powershell-6

You're missing the '-LiteralPath' parameter. I was able to save the module to a Linux folder.

Correct oneliner: (Example)
Save-Module -LiteralPath "/home/maxt/MyModules" -Name "HPOneView.400"    

![savemodule_01_2018-01-19_14-00-04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/35166796-1a592dde-fd21-11e7-9be8-84eed8d8ca3f.jpg)

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Word of Caution! I check for the "Linux" tag for this module "HPOneView.400". But doesn't have Linux.  
So, although it's save on my Linux module folder, it doesn't guarantee that will work. 

Only you can test this module in Linux. If it doesn't work then its a Windows only module.
:)
